This is what Realms is. 

Quoted from site-

"Realms are servers run by us, just for you and your friends. Keep your minecraft world online and always accessible, even when you log off. it's safe to as only people you invite can join your world"

Ik what youre talking about and I see how this is different from realms: its more lowkey, and you're just having fun and not looking to pay all the money for a full on realm that you don't need all the features of. U just want to play a simple game with your friends and it should absolutely be possible to do on your own, I used to do this too.

1 - When youre finished playing, put your inventories and armor in chests and make your pets following you sit down. Write down your coordinates too and make sure you know whos is whos. When your friends leave, and you go back on the world under your own account instead of theirs, minecraft is notorious for mixing up your inventories and locations so this is important as you might end up playing under a different account, it makes it logistically easier but you will be able to know what stuff is yours.

2 - log off everyone and save & quit the world. Locate the world file and make a copy to be safe. Worlds are in your .minecraft folder, search %appdata% in file explorer and go to .minecraft, then saves, then copy your world file from there.

3 - send this world file to your friends, then they can put it in their saves folder and play it themselves. do this over email or share it w them to download over google drive if the file is too big. Zip the world file into one file first. 

4 - your friends can then open up this file on their own computers to play, and since its them logging in and not you, they can identify whose inventory goes to who.

I have 4 kids. My 2 oldest live really far away, and we only get to see them a few times a year. One thing we all have in common is our love for this block game called Minecraft. If Bedrock was officially available on the Quest 2, I would buy several devices, copies of Minecraft, and a Realm subscription tier capable of supporting my whole family.

Imagine if proximity chat was added, this would allow families and friends to spend time together and build worlds together. Imagine college students spending time with their siblings, parents, and friends back home on a regular basis. But even thinking about my son and I who play together at home, how much higher quality this time together could be even in the same room. I can also imagine Realms subscriptions would see a major rise as well, if this was heavily advertised, and increase the overall player base again.

I believe Mojang / Microsoft is grossly underestimating the impact Minecraft could have on this platform. The Quest 2 would not only be the peak of Minecraft immersion and connectivity with friends and loved ones, but would have the best price to performance proposition of any platform, *including* non-VR. Compare this to anything requiring a gaming PC or console. Not only are those inaccessible to most people for the cost alone, but then only a small percentage of those have the time, patience, and technical skill to get the setup working. Certainly my 12 year old would be able to do the Quest, but not a gaming PC.

Hosting a Java Edition multiplayer server is not as easy as it should be and this needs to change. Bedrock Edition is far superior for being able to play with your friends online as it handles the technical stuff automatically. Hosting a Java Edition server requires more knowledge and maintenance. Even if you port forward and get the server running successfully, you will need to reconfigure your server if your IP address changes. Non-technical people do not know how safe port forwarding is or how to keep the network secure while port forwarding. Playing Java Edition with your friends should only require a few clicks regardless of whether you are using Minecraft Realms or not.

It's ridiculous that Mojang prides Minecraft on being multiplayer friendly while in reality the only way to play multiplayer is either buy a realm for $7.99, or spend ages setting up a server (I literally tried to explain all the steps but there were too many characters) and that's the way it's been literally since 1.0 was released. All Java accounts are linked with Microsoft, which means your Xbox friends could be the ones to join your Java world. They already showed off that this could be possible with the Chat Report Feature. There are already a ton of mods which make the Open to LAN function online, and it's actually easier to install the mod than set up the server which is quite sad. If you ask the average Java player what their opinion on this is, they'd say they're perfectly happy the way it is, but the only reason they say that is because the average Java player is either a techno wizard, they play with their siblings with Open to LAN, or they just play single-player (Just like some replies above me). And the less techy people aren't buying realms, they're just quitting Java altogether. If Mojang thinks that if they do this they'll miss out on realms subscriptions, they're absolutely wrong. If a player wants their own private server and doesn't know how to make one, they'll 100% buy a Realm. If Mojang decides to do this it will make their community EXTREMELY happy, and they'd also get a big surge of players coming back to the game.

First of all, don't use the word "we" like that in your post. It is incredibly arrogant to assume that the entire community agrees with you in this fashion.

You also don't seem to understand that running a server costs actual money. If pay-to-win schemes are not allowed, there are precious few revenue streams left outside of adding ranks that offer cosmetic and quality-of-life upgrades to its players. I personally only play skyblock. The reason we need a skyblock world type, is so that the biome flags generate as normal, but no terrain is placed for chunk generation.

This would allow us skyblock players to make use of biome specific effects, like fishing in jungles for bamboo, using rivers to spawn drowned, and experience the ambience of the new Nether biomes. Without having to rely on custom maps.

This also means you can use any seed to generate a different Biome layout for your skyblock.

Also this world type would need to remove mineshafts, strongholds and villages since they wouldn't generate correctly. They could also utilise the "bonus chest" mechanic that already exists to generate the "essentials" required for a skyblock game.

I do agree that Minecraft Story Mode didn't have an impressive story, but the story was a pretty simple and good one for everyone to understand.

The game doesn't just make a story then add Minecraft Elements, it builds a story around Minecraft.
First, we have the wither/command block, then we have the portals and stories around creative items(Skyblock)/traps/respawn, then we have the admin and a reference of deleting old worlds.

The story won't work very well if it isn't in a Minecraft universe, many things would have to change if they did not do it in the Minecraft Universe. This isn't simply putting a "Minecraft Texturepack" on a story, this is a story that builds around Minecraft. Just like Minecraft Dungeons and Minecraft Earth, they aren't just games with a "Minecraft Texturepack" they are games built around the Minecraft Universe.

I would like to conclude that the game definitely has its faults, but in general, the game is at least decent.

I 100% believe that advancements like what Java edition has should be added into Bedrock edition. Since advancements reset per world, and are not affected by any in-game settings, add-ons, or mode's, it gives players a consistant fun goal to strive for in each world they make, without having to worry if a certain setting, or add-on will disable it, making the feature useless. Advancement runs are one of the more popular things on Java edition to do, especially in hardcore worlds, or speed-running getting them, and Bedrock edition shouldn't be excluded from this.

Additionally, they act as a sort of guide for players to learn more about the game, as going through and doing these difference advancements has you achieve new things in the game you may not have otherwise done.
